awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms of Topological Rearrangements in Integral Membrane Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the mechanisms by which membrane proteins (i.e., proteins that reside within the cell membrane) obtain correct orientations with respect to the membrane after protein synthesis. Membrane proteins are critical for cellular functions including transport, signaling, and enzymatic activity. To function properly, a membrane protein must fold into its correct topology, which requires all structural elements of the protein to obtain specific orientations with respect to the membrane. Membrane proteins that fail to obtain a correct topology are rapidly degraded in the cell. This project uses molecular simulation techniques to address gaps in the knowledge of how membrane protein topology is established. This knowledge will inform engineering approaches to maximize correct protein production. The research team will incorporate undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, to train the next generation of researchers in an interdisciplinary research environment. Learning modules based on this project will be developed for outreach initiatives targeted at middle-school students to inspire young students to pursue research careers. Results from this project will also be incorporated into graduate and advanced undergraduate courses.  

This project will use molecular dynamics simulations to study experimentally characterized topological rearrangements in a series of representative membrane proteins. Recent experimental results have indicated that certain membrane proteins undergo topological rearrangements in which hydrophilic protein elements directly cross the membrane, even though this process should face a large energy barrier. Atomistic and coarse-grained simulations, accelerated by enhanced sampling techniques, will be performed to characterize the pathways by which hydrophilic protein elements cross the membrane. These simulations will elucidate the interplay of protein, lipid, and water interactions that facilitate topological rearrangements on biologically relevant timescales. Based on simulation insight, sequence mutations will be tested for each of the model systems to generate experimentally verifiable predictions. The simulation methods developed and applied in this project will also be of value for studying similar bilayer translocation processes relevant to lipid flip-flop, membrane protein conformational changes, or the delivery of drug carriers to cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The cell membrane is a thin barrier that acts to regulate the transport of material into and out of the cell. The membrane is composed of amphiphilic lipids with hydrophilic head groups and hydrophobic tail groups that form a sandwich-like bilayer structure. Embedded within the membrane are proteins that perform numerous functions necessary to cell function. To function properly, membrane proteins must fold into their correct structures, which requires all structural elements (i.e., water-soluble loops and membrane-embedded helices) to obtain specific orientations with respect to the membrane. These orientations define the topology of a membrane protein. While membrane protein topology is thought to be fixed after protein synthesis, recent experiments have identified topological rearrangements in which water-soluble loops translocate, or flip, across the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer. This behavior is surprising because the hydrophobic lipid tail groups should prevent such flipping processes. In this project, molecular-scale simulations were used to resolve the mechanisms underlying the observed flipping processes to gain new understanding of membrane protein folding and to provide insight into methods for engineering bilayer translocation processes for applications such as drug delivery.

A challenge associated with studying flipping is the long timescale over which it occurs compared to the timescales that can be accurately modeled using molecular dynamics simulations. We addressed this challenge by developing new methods to accelerate the observation of long timescale events (referred to as enhanced sampling methods). We used molecular dynamics simulations and enhanced sampling methods to first study membrane-embedded peptides - short segments of amino acid residues representative of structural elements of typical membrane proteins - to understand how variations in the peptide amino-acid sequence influences the flipping of loops across the bilayer.  These simulations revealed the importance of charged amino-acid residues located near the central region of the membrane in promoting the flipping of peptides (and their associated loops) across the membrane. These residues drive the formation of 'water defects' in the membrane that create a favorable local solvation environment which facilitates the translocation of charged loops across the bilayer. Building upon this finding, simulations were performed of helical transmembrane segments from a membrane protein known to exhibit topological rearrangements. The simulations again revealed a high likelihood of flipping for helices that have a charged, membrane-exposed amino-acid residue. These findings provide molecular-scale mechanistic insight into how flipping can occur, the ability of water defects to promote flipping processes, and how specific protein sequence features can be identified to predict the likelihood of flipping.

Utilizing the computational tools developed in this project, we further investigated related processes involving the translocation of charged biomolecules across lipid bilayers to determine if the molecular mechanism underlying flipping generalized more broadly to other molecules. Simulations of quorum sensing molecules, which contribute to the cell-to-cell communication between certain bacteria, revealed that their bilayer translocation again requires the formation of a water defect. Amphiphilic quorum sensing molecules with hydrophilic head groups and long hydrophobic tail groups exhibit similar flipping behavior as membrane-embedded peptides with the hydrophobic tail group stabilizing insertion into the membrane. We broadened these studies to include synthetic drug-like molecules with hydrophobic tail groups of intermediate chain length and synthetic nanomaterials with amphiphilic surfaces groups. Simulations again identified similar mechanisms governing the translocation of these synthetic groups across bilayers. Together, these findings highlight that the mechanistic understanding gained from studying topological rearrangements in membrane proteins can broadly apply to bilayer translocation processes for diverse natural and synthetic molecules.

To date, this project has produced five peer-reviewed publications, with additional publications in preparation. The project also provided research training opportunities for multiple graduate students and undergraduate students, permitted their travel to and presentations at multiple conferences, and contributed to the successful thesis defense of a doctoral candidate. Results from this research have also been incorporated into multiple educational and outreach activities. We developed simulation modules to visualize molecular simulation output related to lipid bilayers, membrane proteins, and bilayer translocation. These modules were included as course material in multiple classes and presented as part of hands-on activities for elementary and middle-school students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Engineering Expo.
